National Access-Civil Practice

When architecture limits movement, the law must restore it.

Threshold Equity Counsel represents tenants, workers, students, and visitors harmed by coercive entry design. Our docket focuses on exclusionary door policies, unsafe swing trajectories, manipulative access control, and retaliatory lock changes. We litigate, negotiate, and audit spaces so movement rights are treated as civil rights.

Our attorneys are trial-trained and documentation-obsessed. We maintain a forensic archive of incident photos, handle force diagrams, entry logs, and witness statements that establish patterns instead of one-off inconvenience. If a space claims openness while repeatedly narrowing who can pass and when, we build the record that proves it.

Rapid Intake Window

File preservation starts now

Most entry disputes are lost in the first 72 hours because evidence is overwritten. Use this checklist before your consultation:

Incident packet essentials
  • Timestamped photos of the doorway from approach, side angle, and interior view.
  • A short memo of what happened, including exact language used by staff/security.
  • Copies of building policies, lease pages, employee handbooks, or posted signs.
  • Names and numbers for witnesses, plus any surveillance camera locations.
For emergency injunction requests

Bring proof of residency/employment, prior access history, and any messages announcing new restrictions. We can draft same-day declarations if facts are complete.

Consult hours: Mon-Sat, 7:00 AM-9:30 PM Pacific. Language support available in Spanish, Lithuanian, and Mandarin.

Practice Areas

Tenant & Co-op Entry Rights

We challenge arbitrary lock rekeying, hallway gate retrofits, and punitive key-fob deactivation. Common outcomes include restored access, rent abatements, and court-ordered policy rewrites.

Recent matter: 41-unit complex forced to remove discriminatory timed-lock protocol and fund third-party safety monitor.

Employment Passage & Safety

From warehouse pinch points to badge-only bottlenecks, we represent workers denied safe, dignified movement at job sites. We pursue compensation for repetitive impact injury and retaliation tied to access complaints.

Recent matter: multi-state distribution employer settled for policy reform, back pay, and neutral access routing plan.

Civic Facilities & Institutional Access

Libraries, clinics, and schools cannot condition entry on arbitrary hurdles. Our public-space team handles agency petitions, injunctions, and consent decree compliance tracking.

Recent matter: municipal building replaced high-force door hardware after independent kinetic testing.

Insight Library

Opinion: “Temporary door policies” that never end

Property managers often describe restrictive entry as temporary balancing measures. Yet records show repeating cycles: tightened locks, narrowed windows, selective overrides, and informal exceptions for favored tenants. If a rule consistently denies ordinary access, the law tends to treat it as structural policy, not a passing inconvenience.

Our recommendation: document each cycle with date, impact, and witness. Patterns win cases because they transform private frustration into public proof.

Field note: the three-camera approach for incident evidence

Single-angle clips rarely establish force, spacing, and alternatives. We advise clients to gather three short videos when safe: approach line, handle interaction, and interior clearance. This method shows whether a person had any realistic route to pass without strain or contact.

Courts respond well to evidence that is simple, timestamped, and repeatable. Fancy edits weaken credibility; clear context strengthens it.

Client guide: preparing for your first deposition

Depositions in access disputes are about consistency. Start with a timeline. Mark the first incident, each report you made, each response you received, and every practical consequence: missed shift, delayed medication pickup, inability to host care providers. Specific impacts make legal standards tangible.

Bring originals, not summaries. We will handle legal framing; your role is accurate memory and concrete detail.
